What is your itinerary? We have rented and leased cars many times. Driving in Tuscany, Umrbia, Puglia, Sicily, Sardinia, Calabria, Campania, Marche and areas along the Adriatic, Dolomites, some lake areas, and from large city airports to those places quite easy. We don't drive in Rome, Florence, Naples, Amalfi coast. We had a car in the Italian Riviera and parked it for a week because trains were more convenient and no parking issues. Also easy to combine cars and trains or other public transport. I suggest you whittle down your luggage. We have traveled easily all over Italy and Europe, sometimes for months at a time each with one small carryon (to meet European discount carrier limits) and one backpack, and we never wear everything we bring. In the smaller towns, we have always found parking a short walk from our accommodations,
and not an issue with limited luggage.

Use the trains! They are easy to navigate and then everyone gets a break. My husband is usually our driver and loves driving, but he was so happy to be the passenger and enjoy the views from the train.

Having big luggage can be annoying on a train, but we were always one of the first ones on the train at the station and my husband could throw my big luggage in the overhead area. I saw other people getting help from others around them though. There’s also luggage storage behind the seats, we slid my husbands medium luggage in btwn. What’s more annoying with a big luggage is walking with it through the city to your hotel in my opinion

Trains are so much better than car. We rented a car for one stretch of our trip and didn't enjoy it all. Parking is stressful, driving is stressful, btw cars are mostly manual transmission not automatic. Cars are much smaller here, maybe problematic with suitcase and if you get a bigger car, then the issue with parking and driving is more problematic. Also filling up with gas or diesel is also very expensive.
Trains are extremely comfortable, spacious and relaxing.

We drove ~ 1000 miles over 10 days (1 to 3 nights per town), and had zero issues, in fact driving gave us so many more random diversions that we would regret is we had missed those towns and sights, as well as ability to stop at an Italian highway rest stop, you should not miss them, great food cooked by real people, bargains, as well as simply a fun experience. We drove everywhere, highways, small and large towns, etc., just planned the parking in advance to the extent possible and even parking was not hard. Zero stress, oh, well, getting used to the toll booths, one time we thought the bucket took cash and with stress learning how to use the tool booth threw in a $10 Euro and jammed up the machine! I can only recommend for Florence as I know it best, so here is my advice...

My absolute favorite restaurant is Alla Vechia Bettola. Until recently, it was a hidden gem known only to locals, but now, a few tourists have started discovering this place, leading them to expand the restaurant a bit. The signature red sauce pasta they serve is unlike anything I've ever tried before; it's ridiculously good. To reach this place, you have to walk through Oltrarno, which allows you to experience the local life more intimately as it's a bit less touristy. Just make sure to book in advance, as it's almost impossible to get a table otherwise. Another fantastic option (a bit more upscale) is Cantinetta Antinori, offering traditional Tuscan food with excellent cuisine and charming decor.

For lunch, I usually frequent either the mozzarella bar OBICA or Fishing lab. If you're a fan of fish, Fishing lab is also a great choice. Don't miss the stunning frescoes on the second floor! For a quick snack, the must-try is the tiny truffle panini with prosecco at Procacci. While it was recently purchased by new owners and might not be as amazing as it used to be, it still holds a special place in the hearts of Florentines.

Additionally, I absolutely love the restaurant at Hotel Calimala, and that's saying something because I usually don't like hotel restaurants. I believe this one is related to the famous Israeli chef Ottolenghi, which might explain why the food is exceptionally good. Their brunch is fantastic, and the Angel rooftop bar is a well-kept secret gem in Florence. :)))

Traveling all over the world, one of my safety check is know the city airport code and check to make sure the luggage tags match the code.Some are very similar. I have had my luggage tag to go to San Jose, Costa Rica instead of California, be vigilant. Mistakes do happen.
